title: INSYDE: a synthetic, probabilistic flood damage model based on explicit cost analysis

uiWidget.caption: The duration parameter specifies the duration of the flood event in hours.
The velocity parameter specifies the pace of the water in meter per seconds.
The sediment parameter specifies the sediment concentration in % on the water volume.
The quality parameter specifies whether pollutants are present or not (1 = yes, 0 = no).

title: A question driven socio-hydrological modeling process

uiWidget.caption: Kp: The model was run for SOP (Kp=1) and three levels of HP where level one (Kp=1.5) is the least conservative, level two (Kp=2) is slightly more conservative and level three (Kp=3) is the most conservative hedging rule tested.

title: Assembly processes of gastropod community change with horizontal and vertical zonation in ancient Lake Ohrid: a metacommunity speciation perspective

uiWidget.caption: Applying a range of 1 to 10 groups and different numbers of directly connected neighbors in the spatial network, our delineation of eco-zones consisten ly revealed that seven groups of gastropod communities showed the highest likelihood. These communities relate to seven eco-zones (southeastern (SE) upper littoral 1–3, non-SE up- per littoral, lower littoral, upper sublittoral, lower sublittoral). The horizontal and vertical distribution of these eco-zones based on 65 neighbors is shown in Fig. 3 (zone terminology roughly follows Stanković, 1960).

Applying a range of 1 to 10 groups and different numbers of directly connected neighbors in the spatial network, our delineation of eco-zones consisten ly revealed that seven groups of gastropod communities showed the highest likelihood. These communities relate to seven eco-zones (southeastern (SE) upper littoral 1–3, non-SE up- per littoral, lower littoral, upper sublittoral, lower sublittoral). The horizontal and vertical distribution of these eco-zones based on 65 neighbors is shown in Fig. 3 (zone terminology roughly follows Stanković, 1960).

Applying a range of 1 to 10 groups and different numbers of directly connected neighbors in the spatial network, our delineation of eco_zones consisten ly revealed that seven groups of gastropod communities showed the highest likelihood. These communities relate to seven eco_zones (southeastern (SE) upper littoral 1–3, non-SE up- per littoral, lower littoral, upper sublittoral, lower sublittoral). The horizontal and vertical distribution of these eco_zones based on 65 neighbors is shown in Fig. 3 (zone terminology roughly follows Stanković, 1960).

title: Automatic Time Series Forecasting: The forecast Package for R

uiWidget.caption: The first letter denotes the error type (A, M or Z); the second letter denotes the trend type (N,A,M or Z); and the third letter denotes the season type (N,A,M or Z). (see https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.9/topics/ets)

The first letter denotes the error type (A, M or Z); the second letter denotes the trend type (N,A,M or Z); and the third letter denotes the season type (N,A,M or Z). (see https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.9/topics/ets)

The first letter denotes the error type (A, M or Z); the second letter denotes the trend type (N,A,M or Z); and the third letter denotes the season type (N,A,M or Z). (see https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.9/topics/ets)

The first letter denotes the error type (A, M or Z); the second letter denotes the trend type (N,A,M or Z); and the third letter denotes the season type (N,A,M or Z). (see https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.9/topics/ets)

If TRUE, estimation is via conditional sums of squares and the information criteria used for model selection are approximated. The final model is still computed using maximum likelihood estimation. Approximation should be used for long time series or a high seasonal period to avoid excessive computation times. (see https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.9/topics/auto.arima)

If TRUE, estimation is via conditional sums of squares and the information criteria used for model selection are approximated. The final model is still computed using maximum likelihood estimation. Approximation should be used for long time series or a high seasonal period to avoid excessive computation times. (see https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/forecast/versions/8.9/topics/auto.arima)
